properties.media:imagetext:
THE NEW ERA AIRPORT.
San Francisco which has always been the threshold to some-
where—now beckons to the world with a tacity that is part
of a boldly unorthodox program designed to carry it into a
new era of commercial aviation.
Aware that tomorrow's travelers will be grabbing moments to
compete for business and pleasure in the space age, planners
have sought to design ease and convenience into the Sar
francisco colt or dedanure and amva- elements that char
acterize flight itself.
From these efforts has come a master plan for a terminal
complex with a pacemaking "new era" theme to launch and
receive travelers.
With the concept of compactness and convenience rapidly
crystallizing in a uniquely concentrated terminal area devel-
opment, San Francisco is not concerned by the fact that it is
reversing the decentralized pattem or oter malor world alr
ports. Only three U. S. cities exceed its passenger traffic; only
four exceed it internationally.
Literal proof of the New Era Airport's commitment to the
principle of customer convenience is the beautiful new
$14,000,000 South Terminal which sweeps in an 800-foot arch
from its connection with the Central Terminal at Concourse
"E".
Another proof is at present a giant-sized hole in the ground
which —within two years-will be transformed into a multi-
level $10,000,000 garage, the first airport garage in the
world. Once through its portals, the traveler will have left
the out-of-doors until he reaches his destination in one of
the earth's four corners.
From the garage a brief walk will take him via tunnel into
either the South Terminal or the modernized Central Terminal,
the structure that gave international status to San Francisco's
Not quite 10 years old during which time passenger traffic
more than doubled the Central Terminal is getting a $5,000,-
oou transtormation including the conversion or men o into a
"jet wheel" twin to Pier "B"-both areas occupied by United
Air Lines and the installation of a 460-foot-long "speedwalk"
in the concourse connecting the two piers.
Twelve million persons will use the two terminals each year
with less confusion and more convenience than 6,000,000 have
experienced in the Central Terminal.
And soon a third, the North Terminal, will be on the drawing
boares. Two more onases or te airoom cardse will oring is
accommodations from the first phase of 2850- which alone
will make it the world's largest - to an ultimate maximum of
ouuu automobiles.
The keystone element designed into the entire development is
the character or service. The paramount od ecuve is conven
ience for people who want to fly.
